 REPUBLIC OF BENIN ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT CREDIT AND PROJET SUMMARY Borrower: Republic of Benin Beneficiary: National Environmental Agency Amount: SDR 5.5 million (US$8.0 million) Terms: Standard IDA terms, with 40 years maturity Proiect Descrinti: Over a period of four years the project would support the development of a national environmental management capacity and help the Government implement the National Environmental Action Plan adopted in June 1993. It would in particular pursue capacity building and institutional support, including streamlining and strengthening of national environmental responsibilities, reinforcing policy implementation and coordination mechanisms, promoting better preparation and enforcement of the environmental regulatory framework, developing an effective information system and monitoring and evaluation capacity. The project would also promote public awareness of environmental issues and the integration of environmental considerations in the education system. To achieve these objectives, the project would finance investments designed to: 1. Improve the national environimental management capacity through support to the National Environmental Agency to permit: (a) better definition of environmental responsibilities for enhanced integration of environmental issues in the design, planning, and implementation of sectoral policies and programs at central and decentralized level; (b) implementation of an environmental assessment policy including finalization and adoption of the regulatory framework, procedures, guidelines, and monitoring mechanisms; (c) preparation and monitoring of the implementation of contingency plans and quality control, including the definition of norms and standards; (d) the establishment of an effective information and monitoring system; and (e) the participation of the civil society in the decision-making process with focus on support for decentralized environmental planning and management. 2. Improve the general level of awareness on environmental issues and foster a change in attitude through: (a) the integration of environmental considerations in the education programs of the primary and secondary cycles and the production of pedagogic manuals for the teachers; (b) the preparation of brochures in national languages for the adult literacy program; (c) the implementation of a sensitization program and local initiatives in primary and secondary schools; (d) a training program and workshops for public officials, trainers, journalists, NGOs and special interest groups.
 - jj - Benefits and Risks: The project would allow the Government to develop the national environmental management capacity required to effectively implement and monitor the priority actions identified in the NEAP. By dovetailing with on-going activities in the country it would reinforce the environmental perspective of sectoral strategies and strengthen institutions in their ability to implement programs, monitor compliance with standards and procedures, implement an environmental impact assessment policy and enforce legislation. It would also contribute to the formulation of sound environmental management policies and the implementation of programs and projects which would better take into account enviromnental considerations as part of the overall development process. The thrust of the project would be to initiate a process of changes in the way people understand, deal with, and go about addressing environmental issues. It would raise the level of environmental awareness of large segments of the populations through actions across a large spectrum, such as the improvement of existing education, literacy and agricultural extension programs or through targeted training and workshops for important interest groups (public officials, media, women's groups, NGOs, etc..). The project would therefore reinforce the national capacity to identify and tackle environrmental constraints and favor the participation of the civil society in a comprehensive education, training, communication effort. The major risks would stem from the difficulty to coordinate and manage long-range intersectoral activities and to agree on a sustainable institutional set-up which Would minimize dissensions and facilitate implementation. However, the proposed approach to strengthen the intersectoral monitoring and coordination functions through a small but effective environmental mnanagement agency, while streamlining and clarifying present environmental responsibilities, and supporting existing structures and the private sector in the implementation of sectoral programs, should avoid institutional conflicts and ease management. Although the impact on the national budget for the functioning of such agency would be minimal, political support and regular budget allocations would be essential to sustain implementation of the environmental agenda. Another risk derives from the shortage of qualified local personnel with background and experience on environmental problems and solutions. To mitigate this risk an important education and training effort would be undertaken

 REPUBLIC OF BENIN ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT PROJECT APPRAISAL REPORT 1. INTRODUCTION A. Physical characteristics 1.1 Benin has an area of 113,000 km2 and a population of 4.9 million in 1991, 65 percent of whom live in rural areas. The population is increasing at an average annual rate of about 3.2 percent. Its geographical distribution is very uneven. Population density varies from 188 inhabitants/km in the coastal zone to about 14 inhabitants/km2 in the North. As a result, 63 percent of the population is concentrated on 12 percent of the land area. The urban population accounts for 35 percent of the total and is increasing at 4 percent a year (8 percent in Cotonou). Benin is divided into three main climatic zones; sub-equatorial in the south, with rainfall between 900 mm and 1,500 mm annually; Guinean-Sudanian in the center, with marked temperature variations and an average rainfall between 1,000 mm and 1,200 mm/year; and semiarid Sudanian in the north, with rainfall of 900 mm to 1,100 mm/year and high evapo-transpiration. Plant cover is relatively uniform, in the form of a very degraded savannah woodland extending from the north of the country to some 50 km from the coast. This savannah is interspersed in places with gazetted forests. Further south are residual forests, small areas of deciduous and semi-deciduous forest, oil palms on the sedimentary zones and coconut trces along the coast. Soils are generally poor, mainly ferruginous. Bottom-lands have a higher agricultural potential, but are generally hard to work. B. Economic situation 1.2 The annual per capita income was about US$410 in 1992. Benin's principal resource is its arable land, which makes it potentially self-sufficient in food in overall terms while enabling it to produce cash crops such as cotton and palm oil as a source of foreign exchange. The primary sector accounts for about 40 percent of GDP, more than 70 percent of domestic exports and employs 70 percent of the active population. The average annual rate of growth of agricultural production throughout the 80s until today continues to maintain itself at rates above 4 percent. This performance, although remarkable, was largely achieved through more extensive utilization of available land. The geographical configuration of Benin, together with the deep-water port of Cotonou and its relatively good road and rail network, allows it to provide transit services for landlocked countries to its north. The secondary sector accounts for about 12 percent of GDP, essentially in the form of manufacturing, cement production and limited offshore oil resources. The tertiary sector basically consists of informal but vigorous trading activities. 1.3 Between 1983 and 1987 Benin's economy grew only slowly, partly as a result of a decline in trade and a collapse of the regional transit traffic, but more particularly as a consequence of the inefficiency and poor management of the productive sectors dominated by the State. In 1989 the Government introduced a program of economic reforms prepared with the assistance of the Bank and IMF. This program reflected a change in Benin's economic policies, the reduction of the State's role in the economy and promotion of private sector activities, a balanced management of public funds, and an improved balance of payments situation. In the same time Benin achieved a remarkable political transition from a Marxist-Leninist regime to a democratic system and put in place an institutional and policy
 framework that permitted to restore growth. Moreover, in order to tackle persistent macro-economic difficulties and to restore competitiveness, a major external adjustment was decided in January 1994 by the governments of all CFAF countries to devalue their currency relative to the French franc by 50 percent. 11. THE ENVIRONMENTAL CONTEXT A. Environmental Resources and Issues Introduction 2.1. Benin still possesses a generous environment, which, if protected and managed with care, should be able to satisfy the basic needs of its population and provide the basis for sustainable development. There are no climate changes or physical environmental problems which would, in the short tern, impair increasing and diversifying production if adequate incentives and sustainable production systems were available. Nevertheless, increasing deterioration of Benin's environment has become a major cause of concern for the Government. The country's economy is dominated by agriculture, and although food security could be achieved and cotton exports expanded with a resulting agricultural growth rate above 4 percent throughout the 80s until today, this has often been accomplished through more extensive land use, expanding the agricultural frontier to protected forest areas and rangeland. The competition between farming, stockraising and forestry, the spread of bush fires, the disappearance of the forest cover as a source of fuelwood, the decrease of soil fertility, the silting-up of lagoons and the consequent disappearance of fish resources, are all being exacerbated by increasing demographic pressure. It is unquestionable that the rapid demographic growth (population almost doubled in the last 25 years) and its uneven distribution between the north and the south with uncontrolled expansion of the coastal towns raises very serious environmental concerns. No substantial changes have been introduced in agricultural production practices while the neglect of the urban environment has led over the years to the degradation of the living standards in most of Benin's towns which are ill-equipped to host an expanding population. Industrial activities are still limited and do not cause major environmental concerns; they need, however, close surveillance. Human Resources 2.2. The rapid growth rate of Benin's population results in 56 percent of it being under 20 years of age, the fertility rate being close to 7 children per woman. This represents a source of dynamism but also an important challenge in terms of education, health, employment and overall environmental absorption capacity given present technology standards. Life expectancy is about 50 years and literacy levels are still low, only 32 percent of adult men and 16 percent of adult women can read and write. These serious handicaps contribute in ranking Benin in the 150th place in the world according to the United Nations Human Development Index. Urban population grows much faster (5.2 percent per year on average) than in rural areas (1.4 percent), showing an important rural exodus which affects mostly Cotonou. The major ethnic groups are the Fon (40 percent of the population predominantly in the south), the Adja (20 percent and of the same origin), the Yorouba-Nago (12 percent), the Batonou (8.5 percent), the Ditamari (6.5 percent) and the pastoralist Peuhl (5.6 percent).
 -3 - Agriculture 2.3. Food production meets on average Bemnn's overall food needs and almost all of it is rainfed. Maize is predominantly grown in the southern departments although it is now rapidly expanding in the northern areas and is the most widely-planted crop (about 450,000 ha), followed by sorghum in the north (130,000 ha), cassava (115,000 ha), yams (90,000 ha), beans (85,000 ha) and peanuts (100,000 ha). In most cases food crops are grown in association, and yields are low. Rice production is marginal, although its consumption is steadily increasing, most demand being met until now by imports. Cotton cultivation has also expanded rapidly in recent years from a production of 70,000 tons of seed cotton in 1988 to about 178,000 tons in 1992/93 and an estimated bumper crop of 270,000 tons in 1993/94. Yields are satisfactory (1,300 kg of seed cottonlha), and the areas planted are still increasing. Cotton constitutes a well-organized subsector guaranteeing a floor price to producers, supplies of inputs, credit, and processing and marketing of the final product. 2.4. Shifting slash and burn cultivation is still the most common practice, to the detriment of the natural savannah. Increasingly, fallow land is subject to bush fires or overgrazed. Constant clearing is leading to the disappearance of gallery forests and bush. Low watershed seepage and heavy runoff result in soil losses which, together with riverbank erosion, lead to the silting-up of watercourses and village wells. Farming is penetrating further and further, including into protected areas, bottom-lands and marginal zones. Declining soil fertility is the challenge for tomorrow's agriculture, in an economic context in which access to chemical fertilizers is still limited (basically to cotton). Mineral exports in the form of cereals and root crops are six times higher than eventual restitutions through fertilizers. Further mineral losses result from erosion and bush fires. Agriculture is therefore a "mining" activity, and the land is being exhausted in the absence of sufficiently long fallow periods. 2.5. In the north, fires are responsible for the destruction of 50,000 ha/year, and land is cleared for cotton and yams at an annual rate of around 1 00,000 ha. The Karimama district in northern Borgou is showing clear signs of desertification, and the adjacent Kandi and Banikoara districts to the south are showing the same symptoms as Karimama a few years ago. Cotton, because of its rapid expansion in recent years, is often held responsible for the increasing clearing of new land in the north and for the loss of soil fertility. However, through fertilizer applications, cotton is the only crop which systematically retums part of the nutriments back to the soil. In the south, demographic pressure has led to excessive fragmentation and a significant reduction in fallow periods, which, with no improvements in crop practices, have negative effects on soil fertility. Land Tenure 2.6. Small holdings predominate everywhere, along with traditional methods of land conveyance and allocation. Average farm size is about 1.7 ha for a seven-person family, the average ranging from 0.4 ha in the south, where only 5 percent of farms exceed 5 ha, to 12.7 ha in the north, with 20 percent of farms over 5 ha. Access to land is extremely difficult in the south, where it is increasingly common for land to be sold and demographic pressure has led to over-exploitation of agricultural resources. There has been no real improvement in production methods that would lead to a sustained increase in productivity. In the north, traditional systems predominate; land is often negotiated and allocated in symbolic terms but the concession remains precarious. The absence of cultivation practices
 designed to promote a sustainable agriculture, has resulted in farmers and stockraisers losing interest in maintaining and managing their land assets. 2.7. The current land ownership situation features complex rules and customs that govern rights to land and water points. Modem legal systems embodying the right to exclusive ownership have been superimposed on the traditional system deriving from collective ownership. The heavy pressure on land in the south is constantly giving rise to litigation among neighbors. On the other hand, in the north, newcomers move into previously uncultivated areas, sometimes in uncontrolled fashion, and are accepted by the existing population, with or without the sanction of the land chief, to the extent of land availability. Unless a deed is registered, there is no legal framework for the registration or recognition of customary land ownership or use. The absence of legislation or of a rural land register, particularly in southern areas where land availability is increasingly rare, means that the land tenure system does not make for optimum use of the land. There is a need to adapt Benin's land tenure policy to the various prevailing situations, without imposing a system alien to local procedures, which are still partly effective. Livestock 2.8. Stockraising, with about I million cattle, 2 million small ruminants and half a million hogs, represents one fifth of agricultural production (9 percent of GDP). About 7 million ha of available pasture are only partially utilizable in the absence of watering points. Three quarters of this area is in the northem provinces, where the low utilization of space gives rise to traditional extensive stockraising. Animal traction has expanded rapidly, particularly in the cotton production zones; it has contributed to the growth of cultivated areas, sometimes to the detriment of the rational exploitation of natural resources. Potential animal production in northern Benin is high in terms of pastures, but is limited by poor management of surface water resources, archaic production systems and increasing competition from crops. Feed and water problems often result in overgrazing and rapid environmental degradation. 2.9. The transhumant stockraising is an increasingly heavier burden on the natural pastures. During the dry season it leads to bushfires and to tree lopping and pollarding, to allow the herds to browse among the new shoots. The straying of animals into crops also gives rise to conflicts with farmers and makes any planting of forest species a hazardous operation. Controlling herd movements is a prerequisite for the integration of forestry into farming systems. While domestic transhumance is relatively well integrated in the national land use patterns, large-scale cross-border transhumance is difficult to control. It is extending further and further into the south of the country, where it is responsible for severe degradation and conflicts. Cross-border transhumance is in principle governed by the Livestock and Meat Economic Community (CEBV)2 regulations, which allow the free movement of herds between Niger, Mali, Burkina Faso, Togo and Benin. However, the articles of the agreement are not suited to the ecological and economric context of cross-border transhumance. 2CEBV in principle governs cross-border transhumance and regulations, which allow the free movement of herds between Niger, Mali, Burkina, Togo and Benin. However, the articles of the agreement are not suited to the ecological and economic context of cross-border tranhumance. Togo does not comply and Benin has become the heaven of Sahelian herds.
 -5- Forests and Fuelwood 2.10. Although some form of tree cover is found on about 65 percent of Benin's territory, the natural resources situation shows evidence of advanced degradation. In rural areas the issue is essentially a matter of changing/eliminating vegetation and reducing soil fertility. The mangrove cover of the lagoon ecosystem is also decreasing steadily. The deterioration results from the pressure deriving from shifting agriculture, overgrazing, bush fires and fuelwood collection. Only some 200,000 ha are still covered with species of economic value, while the bulk of the cover consists of the most open stands, namely woodland and bush savannah. Some 1.3 million ha (10 percent of Benin's land area) are officially protected as gazetted forests and about 4,000 ha as reforestation areas. However, areas of significant but unknown size within these protected areas are being cleared for farming, hunting and stockraising. 2.11. Fuelwood consumption, currently estimated at 5.2 million tons, is increasing in line with the growth of the rural population; this has led to significant pockets of deforestation in some areas and to all-around uncontrolled exploitation. Wood is the principal source of fuel for at least 80 percent of the population. Currently, the cutting of forest timber is prohibited except from old state-managed teak plantations (around 35,000 m3), part of which is exported and the rest is insufficient to meet national needs. The supply of construction poles (about 86,000 m3) from thiinning and clearing exceeds demand. The growing need for fuelwood is leading to deforestation all around the towns, incipient desertification (Malanville, Boukoumbd, Ouake) and a shortage of free fuelwood. In southern areas, the problem is further amplified by the density of the population and the near-complete occupation of the land by crops. There is also considerable laxity in enforcing fuelwood collection taxes and in checking export permits, particularly in the Malanville region, from which significant amnounts of wood are taken to Niger and Nigeria. Wildlife. National Parks and Reserves 2.12. About 750,000 ha of national parks and 580,000 ha of hunting zones are under Government protection along the Benin northern border. The contiguous national parks of the Pendjari and W together with the three neighboring hunting areas of the Pendjari, Atacora and Djona constitute a vast and undivided area. It represent one of the largest and richest reserves in West Africa and still shelters large numbers of wildlife species which have become rare or extinct elsewhere. It extends across the borders of Benin, Burkina Faso and Niger to constitute a protected zone of about 25,000 km2 and offers good prospects for tourism development. The park of the Pendjari has been declared a Biosphere Reserve by MAB-UNESCO in 1986 and has benefited from development projects through the EU (rehabilitation) and the CFD (tourism infrastructure). Today the Pendjari represents a relatively well known reserve which attracts a still modest number of about 3,000 tourists per year and where problems of nomadic transhumance and human encroachrnent are limited. However, with the end of external financing in 1990, poor infrastructure maintenance and weak control measures together with the increasing population pressure and poaching, are threatening the results achieved so far. On the other hand the larger bloc of the W and Djona has been completely neglected, infrastructure and tourism are almost non-existent, poaching and livestock pasturing are very common, fauna resources were considered important but a recent overflight by IUCN indicated a severe resource depletion of the Park. Hunting activities have been permitted in 1990 in the Pendjari and in 1992 in the Atacora hunting zones, but not in the Djona. The hunting zones are attributed under annual concession contracts to private operators.
 - 6 - 2.13. Both parks are in woodland and savanna area and enjoy, in principle, protection by the authorities. In practice they are suffering from poaching, grazing, bush fires and encroachment by farmers and the administration's protection policy has often been ineffective. All these areas are managed by the Forestry Administration through a decentralized sub-Directorate for the National Parks which also has control over a number of forestry posts inside the reserves. The Forestry Administration also collects and manages the revenues generated by tourism and hunting activities through a local fund established during the previous EU supported project. Such arrangements have proven their limitations in terms of involvement of the local communities and associations, incentives to a better valorization of the Parks' potential, transparency in management, cost-effectiveness of maintenance works and local participation. Parks' revenues are insufficient to cover the costs but could be reasonably expanded through better management. Anti-poaching measures and strengthening of the most sensitive control posts of these two parks are now being promoted through the Natural Resources Management Project. Wildlife management pilot operations have also been initiated on two sites bordering the hunting areas with grass-roots involvement of the villagers in the management of these buffer zones. Water Resources and Pollution 2.14. With the gradual thinning or total disappearance of the original tree and shrubs cover, and the frequent bush fires, water runoff intensifies on unprotected soils, erosion accelerates and water source and well replenishment declines, thus threatening the hydrological balance. Ever larger proportions of water reach the lowlands and valleys through soils which have lost infiltration capacity. Water supply in the north is insufficient and there is a need to develop new water points for livestock and human needs. With the exception of the principal rivers and lake basins, most rivers are seasonal. The Niger, Oueme and Mono rivers constitute the main watersheds, the two latter feeding into the coastal lagoon which represents the source of fish production and revenues for large segments of the population. The potential in this area is far from being fully exploited, although past ambitious attempts to develop irrigation schemes have failed. 2.15. Population pressure on the coastal part of the country in the South has generated very important environmental stress with potential threats of lagoon pollution and decline in fish production. Benin's fishing activities, with a production of about 40,000 tons per year, provide some 50 percent of animal protein requirements. Lagoon catch accowuts for two thirds of production. Per capita consumption has fallen by half in the last 25 years; production is still declining as a result of problems of lagoon salinity, siltation and over-exploitation. Siltation results mainly from deforestation of nearby watersheds for fuelwood consumption and for the construction of the traditional fish traps known as the "acadja" fishing method, which, although being relatively efficient, represents a serious threat to the mangrove ecosystem of the coastal lagoon. In addition the eutrophication of the lagoon from silting leads to its colonization by the water hyacinth plant. 2.16. The sanitary quality of water is poor and disposal of garbage and human waste represents another threat to water quality. The urban population growth is likely to increase the pressure on already limited sanitary conditions and increase risks of communicable diseases. According to the World Resources Report, about 66 percent and 46 percent of the urban and rural population respectively have access to drinking water and 42 percent and 31 percent to sanitation or solid waste disposal facilities. Water associated diseases such as malaria, diarrhea and schistosomiasis are endemic and account for high levels of morbidity and mortality. Improvement in environmental health conditions will require a substantial
 improvement in the coverage provided by the water and sanitation services. Monitoring systems to report and prevent contamination cases are almost non-existent. Coastal Degradation 2.17. The coastal ecosystem experiences an increasing degradation. The urban and port development which has taken place in recent years along the coastal areas has exacerbated the problem of beach erosion and pollution. Part of the problem of beach erosion can be attributed to the construction industry which is causing uncontrolled removal of beach sand, and to the Cotonou port management works which modified the sand distribution pattern of the tide. However the phenomenon is generalized throughout the African west coast and has a many more complex and broad causes which are not entirely known and easy to tackle. Coastal pollution is mainly caused by human wastes and oil spills from ships. The small off-shore oil extraction platform could also be the cause of pollution concern and should be subject to close monitoring. Urban growth 2.18. Rapid and unplanned urbanization has resulted in the colonization of areas which are unsuitable for construction and regularly flooded. Lack of land tenure security and of urban development plans has led to serious inadequacy of basic infrastructure, drainage and sanitation services. The social cost of this situation is very high in terms of pollution, health standards, capital losses and unemployment. Waste disposal in the main towns is almost non-existent and it is estimated that 75 percent of the wastes of Cotonou are not "officially" collected although recently some private firms are helping in the collection and disposal of garbage. A small part of it is recycled informally but the bulk is dumped in unauthorized garbage tips which represent a major source of pollution. This is even more worrisome knowing that the Benin population in 2005 would be close to about 8 million inhabitants of which approximately 45 percent may be living in urban areas if the present trends are maintained. The FY92 Urban Rehabilitation and Management project has recently started to help the Government tackle some of the identified constraints. Energy Sources 2.19. Energy consumption is mainly derived from hydro-electric sources and fuelwood. The Nangbeto power plant over the Mono river (60 MW) serves consumption needs of both Benin and Togo. Fuelwood, however, remains the primary source of energy for most of the population. The pace of exploitation of fuelwood is not sustainable and causes serious deforestation concerns. Some projects have been initiated to tackle the problem through tree plantations in the coastal areas and introduction of improved cook stoves. However, the issue remains one of relative cost of possible alternative sources. Fuelwood costs presently only account for its collection and transport, no inherent value is attributed to the resource itself and collection of stumpage fees is not enforced. Off-shore oil production at the Semd oil field is limited (4,000 barrels/day) and oil is exported unrefined; new potential extraction sites have however been identified and could be exploited in the future.
 - 8 - Environmental Awareness and Monitoring 2.20. The notion of environment is still a relatively new concept in Benin and environmental awareness of the issues at stake has started developing only recently through the NEAP preparation process, which was initiated in 1991 and was completed in 1993. The definition of environmental concerns and issues varies considerably from one segment of the population to the other and from the north to the south of the country. Moreover, information on environmental problems and solutions is rare or difficult to access. There is no environmental education in schools nor is environmental science taught in the University. Not only are general education and communication programs lacking, but specific information and data on the status of the environment in Benin are fragmented and obsolete. Institutional communication within Ministries or between the central services and local authorities is minimal. Moreover, public officials lack the capacity and training to be able to respond in a meaningful way to environmental considerations, and issues are often debated in the abstract. In addition to specific local needs including the management of watersheds, forest sites, pasture, etc., there is an urgent nationwide need for resources inventory, updating existing thematic maps, monitoring erosion, plant cover, population density, etc.. Only the recent activities of the National Remote Sensing Center (CENATEL) are progressively catching up with the existing gap. Moreover, the need to establish an effective environmental information system through the establishment of a network of information exchange, has been strongly expressed during the NEAP process. B. Institutions 2.21. A new Ministry of Environment, Housing and Urban Planning (MEHU) was created in August 1991 as part of the reorganization of Government structures. While it is intended to play a coordinating role in the environmental sector, define the regulatory framework, update national policies and enforce the legislation, its focus is presently mostly devoted towards urban environmental aspects. MEHU comprises four Directorates for: Environment, Urbanism and Sanitation, Housing and Construction, and Land Use Planning. MEHU is operationally weak, lacking resources and trained staff to be able to implement any meaningful activities. The role of the Directorate of Environment in particular should be better defined and streamlined with respect to its "green" mandate to avoid redundancy with the Ministry of Rural Development. Moreover, MEHU's responsibilities combine both environmental and development issues. The diagnosis made during the NEAP indicates that, generally speaking, the main environmental problems in Benin are fundamentally linked to the rapid demographic growth, especially in the south, to pervasive poverty, and to the discrepancy between the pace of natural resources consumption and their regeneration capacity, especially for traditional energy sources. Moreover, sectoral policies have until now given only marginal consideration to environmental concerns and very limited enforcement of existing legislation. The most important underlying cause may be the lack of awareness and information of the general public on the issues at stake and the inaction of the policy makers. The most visible indications of environmental degradation are: the shrinkage of forest cover and the threats to biodiversity, the extension of land erosion under its different forms, the general deterioration of water quality, and an unbalanced urban development with consequent degradation of infrastructure and services. A study on the economic impact of environmental degradation was undertaken as part of the NEAP preparation and suggests that a conservative estimate of the annual cost of environmental degradation could be in the range of 3 percent to 5 percent of GDP or about 15 to 26 billion CFAF (see Annex 1). The Objectives and the Proposed Strategy 2.31. The main objectives of the NEAP are to: (a) promote changes in behavior and attitude in favor of a better understanding and increased awareness of environmental problems; (b) restore the balance between supply and demand of natural resources and a better conservation and management of the bio- diversity heritage; and (c) improve the standards of living of the population. The principles behind these broad objectives imply: (a) the participation of all the main actors and segments of the population (public, private, NGOs, University) with particular emphasis on groups identified as the key players in the implementation of environmental policies such as the women and the youth, the policy makers, the media; (b) a focus on awareness raising, information and training; (c) a long term approach and continuity of the process; (d) an approach which builds on existing activities, experiences and resources; (e) the sustainable contribution of protected areas to economic development; and (f) improved donor coordination. E. Bank Assistance Strategy 2.34. Lessons learned from previous IDA involvement. IDA support to the preparation of NEAPs in many African countries has become the catalyst of a process which has initiated public awareness of the environmental issues at stake and permitted integration of the environment in the preparation and implementation of development policies. The Cost of Environmental Degradation 3 A study on the economic impact of environmental degradation was undertaken as part of the NEAP preparation and suggests that a conservative estimate of the annual cost of environmental degradation could be in the range of 3% to 5% of GDP or about 15 to 26 billion CFAF. These figures should be used with caution given the weak data base existing in Benin and the difficulty of carrying out an effective cost/benefit analysis of environmental degradation in the absence of well established shadow prices for the different resources. The environment is mostly considered as a public good, with no costs related to its exploitation while benefits are entirely appropriated by the users. Gratuity, deriving from open access to natural resources, encourages over exploitation and low labor productivity, while the related cost will be suffered by the society.
 - 35 - Annex 1 Page 3 of 5 Many of the environmental resources considered are not tradable, hence in the absence of a market price and national accounting procedures, different methods have been developed to assess the replacement cost or opportunity cost of the degradation of the national resource capital. These methods are all subject to some degree of controversy and arbitration, particularly in view of the difficulty to estimate the real social cost to the economy of environmental degradation. However, in spite of being only indicative, these estimates are essential for the decision maker to understand the issues at stake and permit their better integration in economic planning and allocation of national resources. 4. In Benin, the estimated cost deriving from forest destruction, soil erosion and losses of soil fertility, which are very much interrelated, accounts for the bulk of the total cost or about 70%. This seems to confirm that agriculture production has mainly been the result of a "mining" activity, and that part of past growth may have been achieved mainly through depletion of the national capital. Pollution, mainly deriving from urban growth and partly from industrial sources (cement factories), has direct effects on human health. Water pollution and poor sanitation are directly responsible for the increasing cases of diarrhea, dysentery, malaria and cholera. For the latter, about 7,000 cases (of which 260 fatalities) were reported in 1991. Overall, about 400.000 cases of illness were related to the poor quality of the environment. The cost of treatment and the losses incurred by the national economy in terms of people's absence from productive activities represent an estimated amount of about 3 billion CFAF per year or 14% of the total. Important economic losses due to flooding occur regularly in urban and rural areas with considerable damages to dwellings, roads (especially in rural areas), and agricultural production for an estimated annual cost of about 2 billion CFAF (10%). The decline of fish resources can also be attributed to some extent to environmental degradation and the value of this loss has been estimated to be about 600 million CFAF. Finally, although it represent a threat to the national heritage and to tourism development, the cost of biodiversity degradation and fauna depletion has not been calculated, due to lack of data. D. The main indicators to be monitored in this respect are the availability of the inputs with respect to used resources and the standard procurement processing time (see Annex 6) which would provide an indicator of the performance of the system. Planning and monitoring of input and resources use would be particularly important since procurement decisions will Cetermine the proper and timely project implementation. This monitoring systems would need to be compatible with the project activities monitoring system so to be able to exchange information and enhance the performance of the system. Off-the-shelve technology seems more appropriate for that purpose by making use of compatible Data Base Management Systems (DBMS) and Project planning and monitoring softwa-e. 3. The Outputs. The first step of the planning exercise consists of identifying separate tasks that would be hierarchically codified and implemented over a period of time (see implementation schedule above). Some of these tasks may be stretching over a limited and well defined period of time, some others may represent the core of a particular function which is permanent. In many cases the former will lead to the latter. The project will actually help initiate those permanent functions that constitute the basis of an environmental management capacity. (a) Defined tasks can often be measured by the relevant status indicator which consists in ascertaining, with respect to the initial planning, whether the task has started, is on-going and achieved to a given percentage, is accomplished, or is late. PERT or CPM methods enable a simple management and monitoring of these tasks. Status indicators can also be used as output indicators in cases where the task has to deliver a specific output such as: preparation of a report, diffusion of education manuals, adoption of procedures, signature of decrees, workshops, completion of training activities (see Annex 4), etc... A special attribute (flag) would be used to indicate that a task must provide an output. (b) Permanent tasks would constitute the core of NEA's mandate and will last beyond the project life. To gauge progress towards the achievement of project objectives it would be important to assess NEA capacity to successfully implement the project through performance indicators associated to the different tasks or functions it
 - 57 - Annex 5 Page 7 of 8 carries out such as: implementation and monitoring of the Environmental Assessment policy, monitoring compliance to standards, quality control, assistance in the preparation and implementation of contingency plans, environmental planning and monitoring, etc.. (see the implementation schedule above). Discrepancies between expectations and actual achievements would need to be analyzed to justify the reasons for the delay, the inefficiency or whether the target was unrealistic. 4. The Impact. This element would refer to the impact on the environment as a consequence of project activities or in general terms as part of the environmental monitoring function for selected global indicators. (a) Project impact. The major indicators that would be used to assess project impact would be in terms of * change in behavior or enhanced knowledge of the targeted groups that benefited from the education, information, communication and training program. Surveys would be conducted on a representative sample of the people trained or educated to assess the degree of intemalization and usefulness of the program. e expanded availability and usefulness of environmental information. This would be measured by the capacity of the environmental information network to generate new relevant products and by the increased number of users; * better integration of environmental consideration in sectoral policies. Working groups recommendations and the annual Environmental Status Report would report on the necessity to realign sectoral policies and programs. * effectiveness of a set of procedures and mechanisms to implement an environmental regulatory framework (assessment policy, quality control, norms and standards, contingency plans) aimed at preventing, minimizing, mitigating or compensating for possible adverse environmental impacts. This would mainly translate in terms of avoidance of costs, risks and nuisance due to unanticipated environmental problems. Given the difficulty to forecast or plan possible constraints or harmful situations, indicators would focus on the performance of NEA in ensuring and monitoring compliance to the procedures, Government capacity to enforce legislation, preparedness to emergency situations, etc.. In this respect, impact indicators and performance indicators (see above) would be alike. (b) Environmental monitoring indicators. The Environmental Information System (EIS) Component of the project will define and measure selected global Environmental indicators that are relevant for Benin such as: water quality, pollution sources, evolution of the biomass, coastal erosion, forest cover, biodiversity. The definitive list of indicators and responsibilities for the gathering and computation will be defined upon the beginning of the project. The first report on the Environment that will group these indicators is planned for PY2 and scheduled to be annual. The system that will be used for managing these indicators will be similar to the one used to manage the quantitative indicators of the monitoring system. In addition the Environmental monitoring indicators would
 - 58 - Annex 5 Page 8 of 8 have a spatial component. The same rules for codification will be applied to this system so to enable a linkage with a Geographic Information System. Although these indicators would be important to monitor, their evolution would not be directly related to the performance of NEA in carrying out the project. Codification of the different elements 5. Each element of the system can be viewed as a table that describes all its characteristics. The system will consist of three tables: the input, the tasks and the indicators. They will need to be codified in order to manage the relationship among each other, and to define the expected indicator and timing. This codification will be extended to the other NEA's functions in order to enable the relationship with the other information systems (accounting system and GIS for environmental monitoring indicators). Technical asDects 6. The system should permit easy updating and modification of the planning and of the initial objectives. It should be set-up in an open-ended way so to be able to exchange data with other system such as the accounting system and spreadsheets type of software. When possible, reading data directly in the original format would be preferred to using import/export facilities. The project monitoring system could be used by the client but also by the Bank. In addition to regular reporting, data would be exchanged so to get relevant information and facilitate supervision missions. The data may be sent through magnetic support or through the Intemet network after the installation of a server in Benin. Using commercial software packages would ensure conviviality, economy, possibility of updating and communication with other users. Software packages should be on a Data Base Management System (DBMS). For planning, use of resources and monitoring status indicators, a Microsoft Project type of software would be appropriate. For monitoring of perfomiance indicators a Microsoft Access type of software could be used. It is also possible to provide the monitoring system with a set of filters that will flag the major discrepancies and delays in the implementation and performance of the project and focus attention on specific topics.

doc.abstracts: Over the period of four years the Environmental Management Project will support the development of a national environmental management capacity and help the Government implement the National Environmental Action Plan adopted June 1993. It will in particular pursue capacity building and institutional support, including streamlining and strengthening of national environmental responsibilities, reinforcing policy implementation and coordination mechanisms, promoting better preparation and enforcement of the environmental regulatory framework, developing an effective information system and monitoring and evaluation capacity. The project will also promote public awareness of environmental issues and the integration of environmental considerations in the education system. To achieve these objectives, the project will finance investments designed to: (a) improve the national environmental management capacity; and (b) improve the general level of awareness on environmental issues.
